name: Benjamin Carter
bio: Potter, podcaster, & author of Mastering the Potter's Wheel - www.carterpottery.com- @historyofceramics @brickyardnetwork

social_posts.post_text: You can shop my newest work online at www.carterpottery.com.

On last week’s Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast we have a live episode that was taped as part of the Envision: Woodfire NC conference (@woodfirenc) in May 2022. Mark Hewitt (@markhewittpottery) talks with Priscilla Mouritzen (@priscillamouritzen), Diego Valles (@diegovallespottery), and Carla Martinez Vargas (@carlamartinezvargas) about their ceramic practice, and how they express a personal sense of place and culture within their work. Diego and Carla are part of the Mata Ortiz tradition in Chihuahua, Mexico and Priscilla has made Denmark her home for many decades. Available now on your favorite podcast app. (📸: credit to the artists)

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast we have an interview with Sam Lopez (@slopstudios). Based in San Diego, he makes porcelain pots that are decorated with blue and white patterns that melt and blur in the kiln. In our interview we talk about his family ties to Craft, finding his path in ceramics, and the joys of parenthood. Available now on your favorite podcast app. #blueandwhite

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: It's holiday season, and I have a special offer to celebrate. My daughter’s first birthday is December 22nd, so I’m offering $22 off any order at www.carterpottery.com with the offer code HOLIDAY22. The offer ends December 20th. If you are looking for a podcast-related gift visit www.talesofaredclayrambler.com where you’ll find our tenth anniversary t-shirts, posters, and water bottles. Happy Holidays. #redclaylove
Thanks to everyone who shopped my holiday sale this week. This pitcher found a good home and there are a bunch of pots still available.

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Dawn Candy (@littlesisterpottery). In our interview we talk about the concept of potential energy in nature and how to capture it through drawing, and the balance of making labor intensive work that remains affordable. The episode is now available on your favorite podcast app. #canadianceramics

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: Quigley for the win.

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Chotsani Elaine Dean (@chotsanielaine) and @donald.a.clark. They co-authored the new book Contemporary Black American Ceramic Artists, which profiles thirty-eight contemporary artists working in clay. The book sheds light on the contributions and experiences of African Americans who continue to shape the field of ceramics in the United States. The episode is available on your favorite podcast app.

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: Thirty eight artists are featured in Contemporary Black American Ceramic Artists including @moreldoucet, @ashlynpope_art, Aisha Harrison @howitsheld, and @nathanmurraystudios. Chotsani Elaine Dean and donald a clark talk about their writing method and goals for the book on this week’s Tales of a Red Clay Rambler. Available now on your favorite podcast app.

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler

social_posts.post_text: Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with curator Mary Savig (@marysavig). As the Lloyd Herman Curator of Craft at the Smithsonian’s Renwick Gallery (@renwickgallery) she is one of the co-curators of the 50th anniversary exhibition This Present Moment: Crafting a Better World. The bulk of the exhibition features 135 recently acquired works from women and artists of color who are expanding the canon of craft. In our interview we talk about the curatorial themes of the exhibition, how museum acquisition campaigns work, and the profiles of a handful of artists featured in the exhibition. The show will be on display at the Renwick Gallery until April 2023. Pictured: Toshiko Takaezu, Mary Savig, and Sonya Clark’s Monumental.

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text:
Of the many talented artists whose work was featured in This Present Moment at the @renwickgallery, I have been thinking especially about Bisa Butler, Margarita Cabrera, Chawne Kimber, and Carolyn Crump. They all rely on sewing in their work, which reminds me of the saying “As long as the ties that bind us together are stronger than those that tear us apart, All will be well.” It’s a message that craft and craft artists convey so well. I left the show feeling optimistic about the power of artists to tell the truth through their objects. Hear @marysavig talk about the exhibition on this week’s Tales of a Red Clay Rambler podcast. 
#artpodcast #brickyardnetwork
Our little ray of light was born one year ago today after the longest night of the year. Happy Birthday to Zosia and thanks to @m_brzy for being a badass mom, professor, and partner.
Warm light coming through a cathedral quilt.

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Dr. Kelli Morgan (@thesemuseumstreets) and Jennifer Zwilling (@jzwilling). They co-curated Figuring Space, an exhibition featuring twelve contemporary artists working with the figure. In the interview we discuss the historical use of the figure to portray power, the variety of sculptural approaches used by the featured artists, and The Clay Studio’s (@theclaystudiophl) recent move to South Kensington. The exhibition opens January 12th at The Clay Studio in Philadelphia. The episode is now available on your favorite podcast app.

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: Seeds of Tomorrow by Jonathan Christensen Caballero (@jcc_sculpture) is one of the pieces featured in Figuring Space at The Clay Studio (@theclaystudiophl). He says of the work “Seeds of Tomorrow/Semillas Del Mañana is inspired by the oral histories of Mexican Railroad workers and their families available through the @watkinsmuseum as well as the documentary, Searching for La Yarda, by filmmakers @l.ourde.s and @angelljasso Between 1920-51, these families lived in company apartments that the residents called La Yarda. The stories describe many things but the gardens they grew for food and flowers inspired this sculpture. The gardens nourished their bodies and their seeds symbolize the hopes for a better tomorrow.” Hear more on this week’s Red Clay Rambler episode with Kelli Morgan (@thesemuseumstreets) and Jennifer Zwilling (@jzwilling).

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Lorna Meaden (@lornameadenpottery). From her studio in Durango, CO Lorna makes functional pottery that is decorated with geometric patterns and breaking glazes over crisp incised lines. In our interview we talk about developing a local market and refining forms through repetition. #artpodcast #brickyardnetwork

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: On this week’s episode Lorna Meaden (@lornameadenpottery) talks about the challenge of making complex multipart forms. This punch bowl is a technical tour de force made from soda fired porcelain. Hear more about this on the latest Tales of a Red Clay Rambler podcast. #brickyardnetwork

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler

social_posts.post_text: Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Osa Atoe (@potterybyosa). She transitioned to clay a decade ago after spending years as a musician playing in bands and documenting the punk scene. Her functional forms are decorated with geometric patterns that break under flowing matte glazes in reference to the ever-changing shoreline of the Gulf Coast of Florida, where she lives. In our interview we talk about her path to clay, founding the Kaabo Clay Collective (@kaaboclay)—a mutual aid organization for Black potters, and the documentary Vessels for the Human Spirit, which she is making about potter and educator David MacDonald. #talesofaredclayrambler #podcast

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: Osa Atoe (@potterybyosa) makes great pots and has a keen eye for capturing them out in the world. Here are two of my favorite photos of her work. (2nd image shot by @shooglet) Hear her talk about the influence of water on this week’s Tales of a Red Clay Rambler podcast. #talesofaredclayrambler #podcast

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler

social_posts.post_text: Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Joey Quiñones (@jquinones_art). They use fibers and ceramics in their mixed-media sculpture to highlight the domestic and cultural histories of African and Caribbean Americans. In our interview we talk about their prior career as an English professor and the role of art in understanding identity. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #figuresculpture #sculpture

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: On this week’s podcast I talk with Joey Quiñones (@jquinones_art), a true multimedia artist. Their approach to material knowledge has been far reaching incorporating ceramics, fibers, metals, paint, and any other material that conveys the content of the work. We talk about the methods and meaning behind the piece Still Life for Black Peter, which was made during their residency at Kohler (@jmkac). #sculpture

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Kurt Anderson (@kurtandersonpottery). His ceramics and paintings feature compositions of robots, animals, and human hybrids that are visually playful and filled with humor. In our interview we talk about color dynamics and trusting your aesthetic voice. Available now on your favorite podcast app. #talesofaredclayrambler #brickyardnetwork

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Wesley Brown (@wesbrowncreates). He combines thrown forms with thick slabs to make sculptures and pottery that feels monumental both in their emotion and scale. In our interview we talk about his methods of building and finding a unifying surface that accentuates his mark making. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: This week on the podcast Wesley Brown talks about his path to teaching and his time at East Stroudsburg University, where he is a Fredrick Douglas Scholar. He has a show on display until March 3rd at ESU’s Madelon Powers Gallery. Here’s a snippet of his building process. Follow @wesbrowncreates for more. (📷: shot by artist) #brickyardnetwork #talesofaredclayrambler

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Adero Willard (@aderowillard). After many years as a studio potter, she has recently moved towards large scale sculptural vessels that incorporate dense overlapping patterns. In our interview we talk about surface design, matriarchal influences, and the ways objects hold power. Available now on your favorite podcast app. #talesofaredclayrambler #brickyardnetwork

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: On this week’s episode Adero Willard (@aderowillard) also talks about the exhibition Clay Holds Water, Water Holds Memory. Willard curated the show to highlight eighteen black women or non-binary artists for this year’s NCECA conference. Featured is an image of Osa Atoe (@potterybyosa) along with all of the folks in the exhibition. Check it out at the Contemporary Art Center in Cincinnati.

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with En Iwamura (@eniwamura). From his studio in Shigaraki he makes ceramic heads that reference Haniwa tomb figures using the aesthetics of Manga and Anime. In our interview we talk about developing his approach to cultural artifacts, essentializing the figure, and his time at the Archie Bray (@archie_bray). Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text:
Part 1

I had a really great time chatting with Ben @carterpottery 

I learned a ton from this interview and I k is you will as well 

In this episode you will learn about making slow pro and not aiming for home runs everytime

You will learn why Ben uses terra-cotta clay

And so much more

You listen to this episode by searching Shaping Your Pottery anywhere you listen to podcasts

Part 2 You already have a unique voice

@carterpottery

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Courtney Martin (@courtneymartinpotter). She uses resists to create layered geometric patterns on her forms. The blend of hard and soft edges is highlighted by her wood kiln, which lends the glazes a warm depth. In our interview we talk about learning pattern making from Mata Ortiz artists, hand building large forms, and expressing environmental values through the way she works. Available now on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork #talesofaredclayrambler

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: Saw some great pots today at @smithsoniannmai. #historyofceramics

Can’t wait to see you all at @nceca. Check out the new podcast room where you can join live tapings of your favorite ceramic podcasts. 
・・・
Join hosts of popular ceramic podcasts for hour-long taping sessions on Thursday and Friday afternoons. The hosts encourage your input during the Q&A at the end of each session. 

Introducing 
•The Business of Clay, Rebecca Ickes Carra @themakersplaybook and The Potters Cast, hosted by Paul Blais @pdblais 

•Learning through Collaboration, Wheel Talk, hosted by Ryan Durbin and Becca Otis @wheeltalkpodcast. The Mud Peddlers, hosted by Donte Cuellar  @earth_nation_ceramics and Lindsey M Dillon @lindseymdillon

•Building Communities of Color, Potters of Color 2.0 hosted by Robin Williams Turnage @potter_of_color_podcast. Trade Secret hosted by Adam Chau @adamcharleschau, Guests: Natalia Arbelaez @Natalia_Arbelaez_ and April Felipe @aprildfelipe

•Comedy and Chemistry with For Flux Sake, Matt Katz & Rose Katz @ceramicmaterialsworkshop, Kathy King @kathykingart

•Taking an environmental approach to making, The Kiln Sitters, hosted by Marianne Chénard @chenardmarianne, Tales of a Red Clay Rambler, hosted by Ben Carter @carterpottery, Guest: Julia Galloway @galloway_pottery and Ché R. Ochtli

•Sci-fi, Game Play, and World-Building in Art, The Kiln Sitters hosted by Brendan Tang @brendantang, The Shot Callers, hosted by Justin Paik Reese @jpr_studio and Virgil Ortiz @virgilortiz, and Guest: PJ Anderson @pjandersonceramics

Join us in Cincinnati, Ohio, from March 14 - Saturday, March 18, for NCECA's 2023 Conference, CURRENT.
It’s hilarious to me that IG filters are mostly sweet and created to make cat videos look hip. Then you find one that is made to melt faces.

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Caroline Cheng (@carolinecheng0166). A noted artist and curator, Cheng has recently expanded her practice into environmental design through the Yi Design Group. The company turns recycled ceramic material from Jingdezhen into architectural products. In our interview we talk about launching a design start-up, addressing the issue of ceramic waste, and the evolution of The Pottery Workshop. Cheng is the Executive Director of the @thepotteryworkshop, which promotes ceramics throughout China, and has studios in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Dali and Jingdezhen.

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: Stephen Creech (@creechoftheeast) at I Contain Multitudes, 2023 NCECA Annual. Wonderful work and a great show curated by Garth Johnson @extremecraft.
Saw many good pots at this year’s @nceca. Here are a few of my favs by @samiclayee, @isissa, Jeff Oestreich, @marycale, and @aderowillard. #nceca2023

Check out episode #458 of the podcast: Tales of a Red Clay Rambler. For this episode, Ben Carter interviewed Rober Harrison and myself about the NCECA Green Task Force and sustainability. Give it a listen and let us know what you think! What are ways that you like to bring sustainability into your studio practice?

#ceramics #clay #sculpture #sustainability #upcycledmaterials #nceca #ncecapresenter #ncecacincinnati #talesofaredclayrambler #sustainablepractice #sustainablepractices #greentaskforce #ncecagreentaskforce green

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler

social_posts.post_text: Zosia loves her new Britta (@gonetoclover) mug. We only needed one outfit change this morning. That’s progress.

Robert Harrison (@robertharrison2976) and Danielle O’Malley (@omalley_art) talk about the history and goals of the @nceca Green Task Force on last week’s episode of the podcast. The group works to educate and empower artists to engage in sustainability and environmental stewardship.

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have a panel discussion on taking an environmental approach to making with Marianne Chénard (@chenardmarianne), Julia Galloway (@galloway_pottery), and Ché R. Ochtli (@roble_estudio). In our interview we talk about practical sustainability and the ways you can lessen your studio’s environmental impact. Our discussion was recorded live in Cincinnati, OH last week as part of this year’s  @nceca conference.

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: So fun to see Kristen (@kiefferceramics) and Trevor (@trevortoneyincolor) on my swing through MA. Their home and studios are filled with color and warmth. Loving the new plates I got from Kristen.
Getting ready for a few spring shows and my annual Mothers Day Sale. Look for these at @schallergallery,  @archie_bray, and on my website in the next month or so.

Spanning more than four decades, Sana Musasama’s (@sanamusasama) career has been a blend of art making, teaching, and activism. In our interview we talk about how her travels across West Africa in the 1970s set her on a path to understanding other cultures through art making. We also discuss her activism and why it is important to make joyous objects in light of world events. In addition to her creative practice she has taught at numerous art institutions including Hunter College and City College of New York. Available now on your favorite podcast app. #talesofaredclayrambler #brickyardnetwork

The Topsy Turvy doll you see spinning above features singers Ella Fitzgerald and Sarah Vaughan. The doll form is one that Sana Musasama (@sanamusasama) has returned to over the years as an expression of joy and celebration. In our interview she talks about using dolls to help the girls and women she works with visualize where they have been and were they want to go. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #talesofaredclayrambler #brickyardnetwork

I’m happy to announce that I’ll be jurying The Clay Center of New Orleans (@claycenternola) upcoming exhibition “Less is More”. This juried exhibition is open to ceramic vessels, sculptures, and wall-mounted works, and celebrates earthenware clay and low-fire surface techniques. Application deadline is April 15th so visit www.nolaclay.org to apply today.

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Rebecca Hutchinson (@rebeccahutchinsonstudio). Her 2022 installation Re-Generation at the Everson Museum (@eversonmuseum) featured cocoon-like vessels that were surfaced with drawings of rare central New York Orchids done by artist Mallory Wetherell (@mallorywetherell). This work highlights environmental sustainability and hybridity, two themes that recur throughout Hutchinson’s career. In our interview we talk about structural concepts she’s learned from observing animal habitats, blending paper and clay, as well as her role as a professor at the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth (@umassdceramics). Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: Sean O’Connell (@seanoconnell.pottery) is a great person that needs some help over the next few months. You can support him through a medical/financial emergency via Go Fund Me. Visit the link in my bio to donate.
Working towards my Mother’s Day sale in a few weeks and happy to send new work to @archie_bray for the spring sale. #redclaylove

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast we return to a series of interviews about parenting. For the Meet the Parent series I invited artist couples to talk with each other about finding balance between creative work and life as a parent. Today’s interview features Mallory Wetherell (@mallorywetherell) and Matt Ziemke (@mattziemke). The couple are based in Kearny, NE, where Mallory is the head of Ceramics at the University of Nebraska at Kearney and Matt is a senior lecturer and gallery director. Available now on your favorite podcast app.

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: Dark and stormy bowl interior.
Happy to be part of Taking Root at @schallergallery. Opens April 25th at 2pm. #terracotta

On our recent episode of the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have the sixth installment in a series of interviews about parenting. For the series I invite artist couples to talk with each other about finding balance between creative work and life as a parent. Today’s interview features Courtney Martin (@courtneymartinpotter) and John Geci (@jgeciglass), whose ceramic and glass studio is located near Penland, NC. Listen now on your favorite podcast app.

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: Taking Root is now open at @schallergallery. #redclaylove

There are some great makers and pots in Taking Root at the @schallergallery. Here are my faves from Cathi Jefferson (@cathi.jefferson), Eiko Maeda (@eikoceramics), Matt Metz (@metzpottery), Sam Scott (@samscottpottery), Jim Malone, and Sandra Torres (@sandratorresporcelain). Check them out on the Schaller website.

I added more layers on this last batch of pots. The texture gives the glaze something to move around and pool under, which helps loosen up the drawing. This vase is now available in the shop for my Mother’s Day sale.
Made a few teapots in this last batch. Check them out in the shop for my Mother’s Day Sale.

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Sergei Isupov (@sergei__isupov). Through his unique blend of figure sculpture and drawing he investigates the internal and external forces that shape human relationships. In our interview we talk about his approach to narrative, growing up in a family of artists, and how current events, including the war in Ukraine, affect his work. Available now on your favorite podcast app. #sculpture (📷: Full Moon Addiction photographed from both sides. Available at @ferrincontemporary)

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Philadelphia sculptor Lauren Mabry (@laurenmabry). Her sculptures are surfaced with vibrant glazes that melt to both conceal and reveal their underlying forms. In our interview we talk about expressing ideas within abstraction, her ongoing glaze research, and working with dynamic Gloop glazes. Available now on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork @archie_bray

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: On this week’s episode Lauren Mabry (@laurenmabry) talks about her experience working at Mission Clay (@mission_clay). The program invites artists to work in the factory and supports creating at a scale not often possible in studio ceramics. This episode and more from the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler can be found on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork @archie_bray

Today we’re featuring the work of @carterpottery .

Check out the subtle layers of slip and brushed glaze patterns on this toasty red clay body! We love the layers of process and visible information protruding through the layers. We’re personally a big fan of the plate 🍽️ shown in slide 3 which features an interesting vertical lip and finger mark pattern through the white slip.

Check out more of Ben’s work on our website! 🍻
.

.

.
#pottery #bencarter #terracotta #slipware #ceramics #details #brushmarks #potterygallery #ceramicgallery
Dishwashers delight on a recent serving bowl. #redclaylove

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Anat Shiftan (@anatshiftan). Her sculptures incorporate floral elements that are precariously arranged as a metaphor for the human perception of nature and our impact on the environment. In our interview we talk about her childhood and family history, historical depictions of nature, and retiring from teaching after twenty years at SUNY New Paltz. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: In this week’s podcast with Anat Shiftan (@anatshiftan) we talk about historical depictions of nature and the fantasy’s of human power they portray. While the Dutch masters painted symbols of power from their own time, Shiftan continues the conversation by adding forms from the history of ceramics in her still life’s. Hear more on this week’s Tales of a Red Clay Rambler. (📷: Still Life with Fruit and a Beaker on a Cock's Foot Abraham Mignon 1660’s collection of the Rijksmuseum) #stilllife #historyofceramics

Pete Pinnell (@pete.pinnell) is a long-time ceramic artist who has engaged the community through his numerous articles for Clay Times and his work as a professor at the University of Nebraska (@unl_clay). In recent years he has focused on teapots, developing both high- and low-fire series of his signature refined forms. In our interview we talk about simplifying complex ideas and re-finding your voice throughout your career. Listen to the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork

Pete Pinnell (@pete.pinnell) talks about the influence of Betty Woodman on this week’s Tales of a Red Clay Rambler. She once told him in a critique that he needed to tighten up his forms. This was contrary to the casual throwing style that was prevalent at the time in American ceramics. This jar is a great example of his precise throwing style and keen since of surface design. Hear more on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler

social_posts.post_text: To celebrate the 11th anniversary of the podcast I brought back our original Camp Shirt, a listener favorite over the years. If you become a new patron or renew your support on Patreon before midnight tonight, you will receive a free t-shirt as a thank you gift. Make a donation at the link in my bio. #talesofaredclayrambler
Plate. #terracotta #sgraffito

Just got back from a quick trip to the @archie_bray. Great to see Helena so lush after the rains. The color of this Max Henderson (@mh_pottery) tile perfectly ties into the landscape. Check out his work and the other folks working in the summer studio.

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Rosti Eismont (@rostislaveismont). For decades he was an art director and graphic designer for major magazines, including thirty five years at @thestudiopotter. Parallel to his career in print he worked as a potter and painter from his studio in Richmond, New Hampshire. In our interview we talk about his childhood as a refugee, his approach to design, and the emotional impact of selling a lifetime collection of art. Available now on your favorite podcast app.

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: As a young potter I bought every back edition of @thestudiopotter I could find on wood firing and Mingei. They were a great resource that I poured over again and again. This week on the podcast I talk with Rosti Eismont (@rostislaveismont), who was the art director of the magazine for 35 years. Listen now on your favorite podcast app.

We’re just two days away from air next Solo show!
We’re so excited to have the beautiful work of Ben Carter in our gallery 🤩
bencarter #ceramicwithflower #intandemgallery #onlinegallery #interiordesign #potterycollector

There’s so much beauty in the simplicity of Ben Carter’s organic designs. Check out his work online.
@carterpottery #organicstrokes #interiordesign #handmademugs #intandemgallery #ceramiclovers #ceramiccollectors

This week on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Heidi Fahrenbacher (@bellajoypottery). She runs Bella Joy Pottery in Plainwell, MI making multiple lines of functional pottery. In our interview we talk about her path to being a maker and how working the show circuit influenced her formula for pricing. Available now on your favorite podcast app. #talesofaredclayrambler #brickyardnetwork

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: Since 2021, I've been saving my favorite pots from each firing. The collection of "keepers" is now available from In Tandem Gallery (@intandemgallery) in Bakersville, NC. #redclaylove

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler I have an interview with Simphiwe Mbunyuza (@simphiwembunyuza). Through his large-scale sculptures, he references the landscape of the eastern cape region of South Africa where he grew up. In our interview we talk about his early art experiences, coming to the states for an MFA, and developing potent references to Xhosa culture in his sculpture. Mbunyuza is a long-term resident at the Archie Bray Foundation (@archie_bray). Listen now on your favorite podcast app. (📷: artist’s IG)

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler

social_posts.post_text: Simphewe Mbunyuza (@simphiwembunyuza) working in his studio at the Bray (@archie_bray). He talks about his influences and process on this week’s Tales of a Red Clay Rambler. #brickyardnetwork #sculpture
Textured jug available at @intandemgallery. #redclaylove

Ben Carter’s mugs have the perfect blend of art and utility. 
@carterpottery #bencarterpottery #funcionalmugs #handmademugs #mugcollector #uniquemugs #intandemgallery #onlineceramicgallery

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Maura Wright (@maura_wright). Her recent exhibition Midwest Sweat at the Jane Hartsook Gallery(@janehartsook) in NYC, takes a humorous and critical look at feminine self-care products and rituals. In our interview we talk about working in many aesthetic directions at the same time and blending gallery work with studio pursuits. Wright is a current long-term resident at the Archie Bray Foundation (@archie_bray). Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork (📷: © Alan Wiener, courtesy Greenwich House Pottery 2023)

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text:
So this is what I’ve been able to hang around with all day. Ben Carter’s work @carterpottery has always impressed me, and being able to touch it and hold it and really analyze it has been such a pleasure.
And that’s such a killer teapot… #intandemgallery #828isgreat❤️ #lowfire #earthenware #pottersofinstagram #ceramics #contemporaryceramics #interiordesign #functionalgallery

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have the final installment of a mini-series featuring current artists-in-residence at the Archie Bray Foundation (@archie_bray). In this episode I talk with Janina Myronova (@janinamyronova) about the narratives and characters that are the foundation of her vibrant figure sculptures. We also talk about the influence of Ukrainian folk traditions and the ways her time at international residencies has shaped her. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: In this week’s interview with Janina Myronova (@janinamyronova) we also talk about making large scale single-fired works. Pictured above you can see the sculpture Janina made for the Guldagergaard Ceramic Research Center in Skelskor, DE. Pictured is the Queen of Denmark admiring the finished sculpture. Hear more on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork @archie_bray

This week we have the first in a two-part interview with renowned ceramic artist and educator Linda Sikora (@sikora.studio). We talk about growing up in Canada, her path to being a potter, and how the ideas of service, storage, and display shaped her recent exhibition Darkening Ground at Ferrin Contemporary (@ferrincontemporary). Listen to the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler on your favorite podcast app. #functionalpottery #brickyardnetwork @archie_bray

This week on the show we have part two of an interview with Linda Sikora (@sikora.studio). We talk about the philosophy of education at Alfred University (@alfredceramics), helping students progress through their own expectations, and being in a family of creatives. To view her recent exhibition Darkening Ground visit Ferrin Contemporary (@ferrincontemporary). Available now on your favorite podcast app. #functionalpottery #contemporaryceramics #brickyardnetwork

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Seattle artist Anika Major (@anikamajor). Her pottery features paintings of female figures created with subtle layers of watered-down underglazes. She says of the work, “Each character is a heroine within the space of the pot and allows me to explore my own perspectives of domestic comforts and eroticism.” In the interview we talk about the Cow Babe theme of her recent exhibition and making art celebrating queer identity. We also discuss moving to the Pacific Northwest and building community at Rain City Clay (@rain.city.clay), where she is the studio manager. Listen now on your favorite podcast. #brickyardnetwork @archie_bray

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with Frank James Fisher (@frankjamesfisher). His work in advertising has influenced his use of text and printing in his ceramics work. In our interview we talk about using UV plates for printing on ceramics, developing press molds for ultra-thin slab work, and the value of labor in pricing. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork #talesofaredclayrambler

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: In the early 2000’s Frank James Fisher (@frankjamesfisher) started creating parody advertisements and packaging for promotional products. This approach was a big hit with clients and in this week’s Tales of a Red Clay Rambler interview Frank talks about how they helped push his clay work in a new direction. Frank describes the design of this toy airplane set. “If an aeronautical engineer filled out and mailed a post card, they received a jet airplane kit, a humorous instruction kit, and our client's catalog to use as a shield while they assembled the plane. The catalog gave the illusion to any passing supervisor that they were actually working.” Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork #talesofaredclayrambler
The joy of blueberry oatmeal.

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler Podcast I have an interview with artist, curator, and podcaster Adam Chau (@adamcharleschau). We talk about using artificial intelligence to generate faux historical images, and how this work might reshape the way we think about queer history. We also discuss season two of his podcast Trade Secret and the work he does as director of exhibitions for NCECA. Available now on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler podcast

social_posts.post_text: Today on the show we have a special episode to celebrate the 2nd anniversary of the Brickyard Network (@brickyardnetwork). To raise money for the network, sixteen artists have donated work for an auction and fundraiser. Two of those kind folks, Michael Kline (@klineola) and Adrienne Eliades (@bugaboo_eyes), join the podcast today to help us celebrate. We talk about favorite historical works, breakthrough moments in the studio, and their favorite podcasts. To bid on the work that is pictured above visit the link in @archie_bray bio. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #talesofaredclayrambler
Excited to be in Clay Akar’s (@clayakar) annual Yunomi show. Check out their site for more. #terracotta #redclaylove

Today on the show I talk with Glenn Barkley (@glennbarkley) about his new book Ceramics: An Atlas of Forms. He chose 113 objects in the collections of major Australian and New Zealand museums to establish a broad survey of ceramic history. In our interview we talk about his research process and the unique stories these objects hold. The book is now available for preorder or directly through Thames and Hudson (@thamesandhudsonau). The episode is now available now on your favorite podcast app. #australianceramics

Today on the show I talk with Lucy Fagella (@lucyfagella). She makes a variety of functional pots from her Western Massachusetts studio, including pots for the kitchen and a line of memorial urns. In our interview we talk about the cycles of the studio, glaze development, and her path to making memorial objects. We also discuss the history of the Asparagus Valley Pottery Trail (@asparagusvalleypotterytrail) and their Early Career Fellowship for BIPOC Ceramic Artists. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #talesofaredclayrambler #asparagusvalleypotterytrail

Lucy Fagella (@lucyfagella) made the urn above from a mixture of clay and paper pulp. In our interview we talk about green burial practices and creating an art object that is intentionally made to decay. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #talesofaredclayrambler #brickyardnetwork

Today on the show I talk with Gleidymar Rivera (@gleidymarr) and Amy Sanders (@amysandersceramics). They were chosen for the AVPT Early Career Fellowship for BIPOC Ceramic Artists, a program started this year to provide financial support and mentorship. In our interview we talk about their style of making, balancing labor-intensive practices with the need to make a living, and how they prepared for their first major sale at the Asparagus Valley Pottery Tour (@asparagusvalleypotterytrail) last April. The deadline for this year’s AVPT fellowship is October 1st and you can apply through www.apotterytrail.com. Listen now on your favorite podcast app.

Two weeks ago my friend Paul (@pdblais) crushed his eye while wake surfing in the Columbia River. It was a freak accident where the board hit him at just the wrong spot. There’s a Go Fund Me to help he and his wife over the next few months. More info at the link in my bio. #potterscast
Happy to be part of Material Mugs VIII at @companiongallery. Here are a few that are available in the show. #terracotta

Today on the show I talk with Paul Andrew Wandless (@studio3artcompany). His multidisciplinary career includes sculpture, print making, leather work, and ceramics. In our interview we talk about labor as subject matter, establishing a style across multiple mediums, and the influence of his mentors Victor Spinski and James Tanner. Available now on your favorite podcast app. #ceramics #ceramicartist #printonclay #artpodcast #contemporaryceramics

Paul Andrew Wandless (@studio3artcompany) talks about the reoccurring characters and symbols that appear in his work on this week’s Tales of a Red Clay Rambler. #ceramics #ceramicartist #printonclay #artpodcast #contemporaryceramics

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler

social_posts.post_text:
Between podcaster, ceramicist, and workshop instructor, what can’t @carterpottery do? 👏

We are in love with his glossy surfaces and impressive forms. Who could forgot about the unique colors and motifs on each piece 😍

To find these pieces and more, visit us in person or online at the LINK IN BIO

#bencarterceramics #talesofaredclayrambler #redclaylove #ceramics #ceramicgallery #artgallery #artistsoninstagram #art #artist #ceramicart #ceramicsmonthly #intandemgallery #jewelrygallery #supportlocal #shopsmall #shopsmallbusiness #locallove #supportyourlocalmaker #smalltownbigdreams

Today on the show I talk with Renata Cassiano (@renatacassiano). Her ceramic sculptures are non-objective accumulations often dealing with ideas of connection and translation. In our interview we talk about reusing older work to create new forms, using a concrete saw to shape fired ceramics, and the influence of literature on her understanding of self and art. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #talesofaredclayrambler #brickyardnetwork
It was a real pleasure to talk with Renata Cassiano (@renatacassiano) on this week’s Tales of a Red Clay Rambler. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler

social_posts.post_text: Have you ever wondered how luster glazes are made? This week on the show Alex Thullen (@alexthullen) talks about iridescent lusters and his work at @pewabic. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #talesofaredclayrambler

Today on the show I talk with Alex Thullen (@alexthullen). In his role as ceramic material engineer at Pewabic Pottery (@pewabic) he maintains their line of glazes, including iridescent lusters. In our interview we talk about the mechanics of luster, how the timing of reduction effects glazes, and how his work continues research that dates back to the early 1900’s when Mary Chase Perry Stratton started the pottery in Detroit, MI. To see examples of the glazes we discussed today visit @glazeisjustglasspaint. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #talesofaredclayrambler #brickyardnetwork

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler I talk with Bryan Hopkins (@bryanshopkins). You probably know him from his exquisite vessels, but you might not have guessed that many of those forms are made from low-fire porcelain. In our interview we talk about formulating low-fire translucent porcelains, using a neodymium grate magnet to create speck free clay bodies, and pushing against the boundaries of conventional wisdom in ceramics. Available now on your favorite podcast app. #talesofaredclayrambler #brickyardnetwork

Make and Do is thrilled to announce that they are offering a scholarship to the 2023 @newclayconference in Ottawa, Ontario. I'm excited to be demonstrating at this year's conference with Martina Lantin, Zoe Pinnell, and Marina Lespérance Lopez.

To be eligible you must:

✅ Be a ceramic artist/potter/art student, currently living, working, and/or studying in Canada.
✅ Be committed to advancing Canadian ceramics and learning through their own studio practice, work, and life.

To apply visit the link in @make_and_do_ceramics bio. #canadianceramics

“🚀 New Clay Conference 2023 is just around the corner! 🏺 Get ready to embark on a clay adventure like never before. Join us for a weekend filled with innovative techniques, inspiring artists, and endless possibilities in the world of ceramics. It’s time to shape your creativity in new ways! Secure your spot today and be part of the fun! 🌟

Our incredible presenters @carterpottery @lantinceramics @zopinnell and @1loma are geared up to drop some serious ceramic knowledge. 

Questions? Ask away in the comments below or drop us a DM.

#canadianceramics #canadianpottery #ottawapottery #poterie #poterieartisanale #NewClayConference #PotteryUnleashed #CreativeClay #ceramicworkshop #potteryworkshop #nerikomipottery #lowfireceramics #earthenware #decorativeceramics #illustrativeceramics

Today on the show I talk with Catherine White (@artistpotter). Her wood fired vessels incorporate firing patterns from her anagama kiln and text from poetry that she monoprints with ash onto the pot’s surfaces. In our interview we talk about her triumvirate of painting, pottery, and movement, as well as, learning the geography of a wood kiln. This episode concludes with an excerpt from the panel discussion “The Thread you Follow” from the last NC wood fire conference in 2022. White organized the panel featuring Naomi Dalglish, Lindsay Oesterritter, and Linda Christianson. Available now on your favorite podcast app.
On this week’s show Catherine White (@artistpotter) talks about her monoprinting process with clay and wood ash. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #talesofaredclayrambler
We accidentally fed Zosia after midnight and she multiplied.

“New Clay Conference 2023 is almost here! Join us for a weekend of clay exploration. Discover innovative techniques, hear from inspiring artists, and unlock your creative potential in ceramics. Secure your spot now! 🌟

Our presenters, including @carterpottery, @lantinceramics, @zopinnell, and @1loma, are ready to share their ceramic knowledge.

Have questions? Ask in the comments or send us a message.

#Ceramics #Pottery #NewClayConference #Artists #Workshop #CeramicArt #canadianceramics #canadianpottery #poteriecanadienne

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler I talk with Haakon Lenzi (@haakonlenzi). A life-long New Yorker, Haakon makes slipware pots from his studio in East Harlem. In our interview we talk about marbleizing slip on the surface of a pot, sustaining a career in the city, and the value of community building through sales and tours. Haakon has participated in the Hudson Valley Pottery tour since its beginning. You can find him this weekend October 21st and 22nd as a guest of Doug Peltzman for the 7th annual HVP tour (@hudsonvalleypotterytour). Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork #slipware

The New Clay Conference (@newclayconference) was fantastic. Great fun to share the stage with Martina Lantin (@lantinceramics), Marina Lopez (@1loma), and Zoe Pinnell (@zopinnell), as well as my buds Carole Epp (@musingaboutmud) and Marianne Chenard (@chenardmarianne. Thanks to Kaitlyn Brennan (@kaitlynabrennan) and the Shenkman Center for the Arts staff for putting on a great event. (📷: @jacquieblondin, Camille Abeille)

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler I talk with Jonathan Christensen Caballero (@jcc_sculpture). He pays homage to local Latino histories through his mixed media sculptures. In our interview we talk about his interest in local history and the practical aspects of making large scale sculptures. Pictured is Caballero’s work Seeds of Tomorrow. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #sculpture #contemporaryceramics

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler

social_posts.post_text: This week on the show Jonathan Christensen Caballero (@jcc_sculpture) talks about his method for blending fibers and ceramics. To create his color palette he contrasts the saturated colors of deconstructed garments with terra sig skin tones. Hear more about his process on the latest Tales of a Red Clay Rambler. #terrasigillata

Today on the show I talk with Dirk Staschke (@dirk_staschke). His recent work draws from Dutch Vanitas paintings, often incorporating ceramic frames that are portals into the inner world of the sculpture. In our interview we talk about exploring dark humor and beauty simultaneously, and having the patience for new ideas to solidify over time. Available now on your favorite podcast app. #talesofaredclayrambler

On this week’s interview with Dirk Staschke (@dirk_staschke) we talk about transitioning between bodies of work and knowing when the next big idea is right around the corner. Pictured are his early figurative work, and two pieces from his series referencing Vanitas paintings. Hear more on your favorite podcast app. #talesofaredclayrambler #sculpture

Today on the show I talk with Trevor Daugherty (@trevorclayworks) and Justin Rothshank (@jrothshank), cofounders of the Northern Indiana Clay Alliance (@indianaclayorg). The group has over sixty members and organizes a variety of ceramics programing in the region, including the Michiana Pottery Tour (@michianapotterytour). In our interview we talk about the process of founding a nonprofit, ceramics in the Michiana region, and fundraising for new organizations. Listen to the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork #michianapotterytour

Thrilled to be in this month’s @ceramics_monthly talking about podcasting and the @brickyardnetwork. It’s available on newsstands now and online at the link in my bio. Thanks to CM and our Brickyard Network listeners for supporting us. The second image features a few of the folks I’ve been able to interview on the  #talesofaredclayrambler over the years. I’m especially grateful to them for sharing their time and experience. (Photo by Dominic Episcopo.)

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler I welcome back Naomi Dalglish and Michael Hunt (@bandanapottery). In our interview we talk about the themes in their exhibition Endless Ground, now on display at the Penland Gallery (@penlandgallery). The exhibition features sculpture, a large-scale slip painting, and collections of vessels that are decorated with slips and wax resist decoration. Available now on your favorite podcast app.

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler

social_posts.post_text: Got to see @oldchurchpotteryshow in person today after years of wanting to visit. Great to catch up with friends and see so many great pots.

From now until the end of December I’m having a merch sale, including this brand new long sleeve t-shirt hoodie. It’s made from a soft triblend fabric that will stretch with you while keeping you warm in the studio. Use the code REDCLAYRAMBLER at checkout to get 20% off your purchase. Shop now at the link in my bio. #talesofaredclayrambler

Some great work by a wonderful human being, Ben Carter @carterpottery . His podcast, the Red Clay Rambler www.talesofaredclayrambler.com which interviews ceramicists from all over, is doing a fundraiser to keep this listening gem going. Check out both him and his work. #intandemgallery #redclayramblerpodcast #ceramicartists #earthenware #claypeople #clayart #828isgreat❤️
Launched my holiday sale with a big batch of new work. Excited about the flowing glaze on this mug. www.carterpottery.com

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler I welcome back Doug Peltzman (@dougpeltzman). A few years ago he made a major shift in his studio practice, essentializing his approach to surface design to create a new aesthetic. In our interview we talk about nourishing the kernel of an idea, and re-engaging his customers after a major shift in the studio. This teapot and ewer show Doug’s transition from inlayed porcelain to stoneware. Hear more on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler

social_posts.post_text: Doug Peltzman’s (@dougpeltzman) transition to stoneware freed up an impulse to improvise with color and surface. We talk about the new body of work and the influence of skate culture in this week’s Tales of a Red Clay Rambler. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork
Thanks to everyone for shopping my holiday sale. Greatful to have the support of collectors and friends.
My holiday sale ends tomorrow at midnight. Shop now at the link in my bio. #redclaylove

Kim Dickey’s (@kimpdickey) exhibition Auguries features the six by nine foot wall piece Sixth Sense, made from over two thousand majolica-painted quatrefoils. The work references The Lady and the Unicorn from the Musee de Cluny, with the important distinction that all human elements have been removed to foreground the gardens’ flora and fauna. In this week’s episode Kim talks about her practice of foregrounding the background, turning place into a character within a narrative. Listen to Tales of a Red Clay Rambler on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork #majolica

Today on the podcast I talk with sculptor Kim Dickey (@kimpdickey) about her use of the Rococo practice of brocage and her feminist claiming of space through ornamentation. Pictured are multiple works from her exhibition Auguries now on display at the Robischon Gallery in Denver, CO. Listen to the episode now on your favorite podcast app. #talesofaredclayrambler #sculpture

Today on the show I talk with Matt Katz, who along with his wife Rose, is one of the co-founders of Ceramics Materials Workshop (@ceramicmaterialsworkshop). They offer online classes in ceramics chemistry, which are utilized by artists and students around the world. In our interview we talk about his path from maker to researcher, how to make chemistry exciting for students, and the podcast For Flux Sake, which Matt is cohost on. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork

Today on the show I talk with Brad Schwieger (@bradschwieger). He has recently retired from Ohio University (@ouceramics), where he helped guide the ceramic program for over thirty years. In our interview we talk about creating a rigorous learning environment, using subtractive methods to find form, and transitioning to full time studio work in retirement. Listen to the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler now on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork #ceramics #ceramicartist #artpodcast

In today’s interview Brad Schwieger (@bradschwieger) also talks about the design of his studio and love of soda firing. Brad wrote about his studio in the December 2022 Studio Visit in Ceramics Monthly (@ceramics_monthly). Listen to the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler now on your favorite podcast app. #brickyardnetwork #ceramics #ceramicartist #artpodcast

Today on the Tales of a Red Clay Rambler I talk with Kyungmin Park (@kyungminpark929). In our interview we talk about how an early interest in animation led her to figure sculpture, how she approaches identity through the work, and settling down in Massachusetts after moving fifteen times in the eighteen years she has lived in the United States. Park is an Associate Professor at Endicott College in Beverly, MA. Listen now on your favorite podcast app. #ceramicartist #artpodcast #contemporaryceramics #talesofaredclayrambler #brickyardnetwork

text_entities.entity: tales of a red clay rambler

social_posts.post_text: This week on the show Kyungmin Park (@kyungminpark929) and I talk about her approach to  the figure and how she builds narratives around them. Pictured are ‘Appletown’ and ‘Jan 06, 2006’, which both show her autobiographical approach. Listen to our conversation now on your favorite podcast app. #contemporaryceramics #talesofaredclayrambler #brickyardnetwork
Potter, podcaster, & author of Mastering the Potter's Wheel - www.carterpottery.com- @historyofceramics @brickyardnetwork
